French students have become better informed about secularism, but also more critical
subhead: More aware than previous generations, French students are also more willing to question laïcité, the French concept of secularism – particularly in the name of individual freedom. For teachers, dialogue remains central to teaching these principles.

title: Trump slams 'decaying' Europe, urges Ukraine to hold elections

byline: By Arnaud Leparmentier (San Francisco (United States) correspondent)

title: Europeans reject confrontation with US over Ukraine
subhead: Skeptical of the American peace plan for Ukraine, which aligns with Moscow's wishes and from which they have been excluded, European officials have chosen a muted response toward the US.
byline: By Claire Gatinois and Philippe Ricard

title: Russia refuses to yield after 11 years of failed peace negotiations on Ukraine
subhead: Since the war began in 2014, every attempt at negotiation to end the conflict has failed, with Moscow violating every agreement. Today, with Europe sidelined and the Americans aligning with Russia's views, Vladimir Putin is convinced he holds the upper hand.
byline: By Marie Jégo and Faustine Vincent

title: Nobel cancels event, raising questions over Peace Prize winner Machado's whereabouts
subhead: Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on October 10 for her efforts to bring democracy to Venezuela, challenging the iron-fisted rule of Nicolas Maduro, who has been president since 2013.

title: Syrians celebrate 'renewed hope' one year after the fall of the Assad dictatorship
subhead: In Damascus, where a military parade took place, many Syrians celebrated on Monday the first anniversary of the end of 14 years of civil war. However, among Christian, Druze and Alawite minorities, as well as in regions administered by Kurdish authorities, feelings remain mixed.
byline: By Hélène Sallon (Damascus, Eastern Ghouta, special correspondent)

The incomplete transformation of Syria's Ahmed al-Sharaa, Islamist rebel turned president
subhead: 'Syria after Assad' (1/4). The man who toppled Syria's Baathist regime has succeeded in breaking the country's international isolation. Yet the former jihadist, who governs with a handful of loyal followers, has struggled to defuse the sectarian and ethnic tensions left by the civil war.
byline: By Hélène Sallon (Damascus, Syria, special correspondent) and Madjid Zerrouky (Damascus, Syria, special correspondent)

title: For this pilot's widow, Sarkozy's Libyan funding case is personal
subhead: The 1989 bombing of UTA Flight 772, ordered by the Libyan regime of Muammar Gaddafi, robbed Maryvone Raveneau of her husband. As a plaintiff in the trial of Nicolas Sarkozy, who is accused of having struck a deal with Gaddafi, she has been disappointed by the media battle waged by the former French president and his supporters.

title: The lawyer suing far-right French mayors for setting up Nativity scenes
subhead: French courts have repeatedly ruled that installing Nativity scenes in town halls is a breach of the 1905 law separating the churches and the state. Sophie Mazas works tirelessly to ensure the principle of 'laïcité' is enforced.
byline: By Agathe Beaudouin (Nîmes (southern France), special correspondent)

title: Sarkozy's astonishing about-face on the far right
'With 'The American Revolution' series, director Ken Burns warns against the tendency to judge heroes of the past through the eyes of the present'
